question: Question_01_(f)
statement:
\textbf{Short answer questions: Each question carries 6 marks, your
answers should quote the results being used and show your work.}

Define a Carmichael number. Use the necessary and sufficient condition
for a number to be a Carmichael number to show that 561 is a Carmichael
number.
sols:
A Carmichael number is a composite number \emph{n} which satisfies

$\displaystyle b^{n-1} \equiv 1 \mod{n}$

for all integers with $\displaystyle \gcd(b,n) = 1$.

For 561, we use Korselt's criterion which states that for each prime
dividing \emph{n}, we must check that $\displaystyle (p-1)\mid(n-1)$.
Since

$\displaystyle 561 = 3 \cdot 11 \cdot 17$

we check that

\begin{align*}
(3-1) &= 2 \mid 560 \\
(11-1) &= 10 \mid 560 \\
(17-1) &= 16 \mid 560
\end{align*}

valid since $\displaystyle 560 = 2^{4} \cdot 5 \cdot 7$. Thus 561 is a
Carmichael number.
hints:
Recall Korselt's criterion which states that a positive composite
integer \emph{n} is a Carmichael number if and only if \emph{n} is
square free and for all prime divisors \emph{p} of \emph{n}, it is true
that $\displaystyle (p-1) \mid (n-1)$
